item.title: Ireland Warns Thousands of Jobs at Risk From Pharma Tariffs
item.description: Ireland plans to use its budget cushion to pump money into infrastructure to protect competitiveness as global trade turmoil and tariffs threaten thousands of jobs in the multinational hub.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher, Laura Noonan, Stephen Carroll

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe speaks during Bloomberg’s Future of Finance in Ireland event in Dublin, on June 23. Photographer: Dean O'Brien/Bloomberg

item.title: Iran Pledges Decisive Reply to US Strikes; Qatar Closes Airspace
item.description: Iran pledged to respond “proportionately and decisively” to US strikes at the weekend and Qatar suspended traffic over its airspace, amid signs American bases there could be targeted as the conflict between the Islamic Republic and Israel showed signs of boiling over.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Fiona MacDonald, Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: Iranians check an Iranian Red Crescent ambulance that was destroyed during an Israeli strike in Tehran on June 23.

item.title: Spain and Rutte Locked in Defense Showdown on Eve of NATO Summit
item.description: By refusing to agree spending increases to appease US President Donald Trump, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez threatens to derail a NATO summit that Secretary General Mark Rutte needs to run smoothly for the sake of the military alliance’s future survival.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Sanchez in Albania last month.

item.title: Ukrainian Deputy Prime Minister Ensnared in Corruption Probe
item.description: A Ukrainian deputy prime minister said he’s cooperating with authorities after the nation’s anti-graft watchdogs announced that a senior official is a suspect in a corruption investigation.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova, Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: Oleksiy Chernyshov, chief executive officer of NJSC Naftogaz Ukrainy, during an interview in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024. Naftogaz is Ukraine’s state-run gas company.

item.title: Qatar Suspends Air Traffic; US, UK Urge Citizens to Shelter
item.description: Qatar suspended air traffic on Monday after the US and UK governments told citizens based in the Gulf state to shelter in place, amid fears that Iran will target US military assets in retaliation for strikes on its nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace, Fiona MacDonald

media:content.media:description: The al-Udeid Air Base in Doha in 2021.

item.title: Trump Warns Against Rising Oil Prices Following Iran Attack
item.description: President Donald Trump demanded that energy producers push down crude prices following US military strikes on Iran, amid fears that an escalating Middle East conflict and supply disruptions could extend the recent surge on oil markets.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Tyler Kendall, Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Oil storage tanks in Sealy, Texas.

item.title: Romania Unveils $6.8 Billion Fiscal Plan as Cabinet Approved
item.description: Romania’s new government unveiled plans to scale back the budget deficit by 30 billion lei ($6.8 billion) this year as part of a broader package that may involve a one-off bank levy and pension and wage caps.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

item.title: Satellite Images Suggest US Avoided Iran’s Nuclear Reactors
item.description: Pictures show the destruction at the Isfahan facility doesn’t include the buildings likely housing three research reactors.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: A satellite image showing destroyed buildings at the Isfahan nuclear technology center after recent airstrikes.

item.title: Israel and Iran Trade Strikes as World Awaits Response to US
item.description: Israel ratcheted up attacks on Iran while Tehran vowed to retaliate against US strikes on its nuclear facilities, fueling fears of a wider war in the Middle East and unnerving global markets.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Jonathan Tirone, Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: The Isfahan Nuclear Technology and Research Center after recent airstrikes on June 22. Source: Satellite image ©2025 Maxar Technologies

item.title: Senate Readies Tax Bill for Vote as Holdouts Threaten Delay
item.description: President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending agenda is nearing a climactic vote in the Senate this week in the wake of air strikes on Iran, which risk embroiling the US in a prolonged Middle East conflict.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The Senate side of the US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Angola, US Firm to Sign Pact to Build $1.5 Billion Power Line
item.description: Symbion Power unit Hydro-Link will sign a pact with Angola’s government on Tuesday to build a $1.5 billion private transmission line that will connect hydropower sites with mines producing critical minerals in neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.dc:creator: Paul Burkhardt

item.title: Japan Says No US Demand for Defense Spending Worth 3.5% of GDP
item.description: Japan denied a report that the US directly asked Tokyo to raise its defense spending to 3.5% of annual gross domestic product, with its top government spokesman saying that the amount of spending was less important than how Japan raises its military capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Sarah Hilton, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: The Japan Self Defense Forces. Photographer: Keith Bedford/Bloomberg

item.title: Pakistan Condemns US Strikes in Iran While Embracing Trump
item.description: Pakistan condemned the US’s bombing of nuclear sites in Iran while at the same time taking steps to build stronger ties with President Donald Trump, suggesting limits to how far Islamabad will go in supporting Tehran in the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider, Jon Herskovitz

media:content.media:description: Protesters demonstrate against the US and Israel, in Karachi, Pakistan, on June 22.

item.title: Texas Governor Vetoes Hemp Bill That Aimed to Crack Down on THC
item.description: Texas Governor Greg Abbott vetoed a bill that would have banned recreational THC products made from hemp, leaving open a loophole that has allowed shops to sell edibles, joints and drinks that create a high similar to marijuana.
item.dc:creator: Joe Lovinger

media:content.media:description: Unprocessed harvested hemp in Houston in 2021. Photographer: Godofredo A. Vasquez/Houston Chronicle/Getty Images

item.title: A Weakened Iran Can Still Inflict Pain on the US — and the World
item.description: When the dust settled on Iran’s nuclear sites on Sunday after a US bombing raid that President Donald Trump said had “totally obliterated” its atomic program, one thing was still missing: its highly enriched uranium, which international authorities haven't seen for more than a week.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Portraits of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and late leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, as demonstrators protest US strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities, in downtown Tehran on June 22.

item.title: Germany to Increase Core Defense Spending to 3.5% of GDP by 2029
item.description: Germany is planning to lift core defense spending to 3.5% of gross domestic product over the next five years as part of a massive increase in government investment in the military.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil, right, and Friedrich Merz during a cabinet meeting in Berlin in May.

item.title: Donohoe Says He Plans to Keep Irish Bank Bonus Cap in Place
item.description: Ireland’s Finance Minister ruled out scrapping a bonus tax imposed on the domestic Irish banks.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Ireland’s Donohoe Sees Energy, Trade Risk From Mideast Tensions
item.description: Tensions in the Middle East are adding risk in the energy and trade sectors, according to the Eurogroup President.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe

item.title: NYC Mayoral Race Tightens as New Poll Shows Mamdani Primary Win
item.description: The outcome of the race could help define the path forward for the Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Arvelisse Bonilla Ramos

media:content.media:description: Voters cast ballots at a polling station on the last day of early voting for the New York City mayoral Democratic primary in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Sunday, June 22, 2025. The mayoral race has become one of the most crowded in recent memory, with at least nine Democrats with significant fundraising numbers running in this month's primary.

item.title: South Africa’s Biggest Political Party Regains Ground, Poll finds
item.description: Support for South Africa’s biggest political party rebounded after it was forced to scrap plans to raise value-added tax and now stands at 40%, the same as it garnered in last year’s elections, while the nation’s coalition government enjoys widespread popularity, an opinion poll found.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: The ANC logo.

item.title: US Braces for ‘Low-Level’ Cyberattacks by Iran After Airstrikes
item.description: US officials are warning businesses to brace for potential Iranian cyberattacks following American airstrikes on the country’s nuclear sites, an event that experts say could draw a relatively small response from hackers.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Howell O'Neill

media:content.media:description: Protesters demonstrate against US strikes on Iran, in Tehran, on June 22.

item.title: New York to LA Ramp Up Security After US Airstrikes on Iran
item.description: Major US cities are tightening security after President Donald Trump unleashed airstrikes on Iran, a direct military intervention that’s deepened Washington’s role in Israel’s war with Tehran and raised concerns about potential retaliation.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: ホワイトハウス周辺のラファイエット広場は封鎖された（21日）

item.title: Decoy Stealth Bombers and Tomahawk Missiles: How the US Hit Iran
item.description: The heart of operation “Midnight Hammer” was a feint.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

item.title: Debate Rages Within Israel on When to Stop Strikes Against Iran
item.description: Israel’s warplanes kept up attacks on Iranian missile systems, airfields and the Fordow nuclear site following US strikes at the weekend, as debate raged in the country over how long the campaign should continue.
item.dc:creator: Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: A fire at the oil depots of Shahran, northwest of Tehran, on June 15. Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Iran Says US Caused Irreparable Harm to Treaty on Nuclear Arms
item.description: Iran said US strikes on its nuclear sites over the weekend have delivered an “irreparable blow” to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty — a bedrock, international agreement preventing the spread of atomic bombs.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone, Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Iran’s IAEA envoy Reza Najafi in Vienna on June 23. Photographer: Joe Klamar/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Thailand Targets Cambodian Scam Centers as Border Dispute Rages
item.description: Thailand announced a raft of security and trade measures to cripple transnational crime syndicates in Cambodia, as Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra seeks an upper hand in a simmering border dispute with its neighbor.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Cambodian people waiting to enter Thailand line up at the International Border Checkpoint of Poipet, Banteay Meanchey province, Cambodia, June 8, 2025. Thai Foreign Ministry spokesperson Nikorndej Balankura said on Monday that since Cambodia has shortened the permitted stay for Thai nationals to seven days, Thailand has also adjusted its policy accordingly, setting the limit of Cambodian nationals' stay in Thailand to seven days. Touch Sokhak, deputy spokesperson for Cambodia's Ministry of Interior, said on the same day that in response to Thailand's cut of the visa-stay period for Cambodian citizens, Cambodia has shortened the permitted stay for Thai citizens from 60 days to seven days. (Photo by Meanchey/Xinhua via Getty Images)

item.title: Farage Promises Non-Doms Tax Protection on Overseas Assets
item.description: Nigel Farage said his Reform UK Party would “bring back” wealthy foreigners who have left Britain by giving them a full exemption from taxes on their overseas assets in return for a once-a-decade fee that would fund cash payments to low-income workers.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Nigel Farage

item.title: More Deaths in Kyiv as Russia Hits Civilian Infrastructure
item.description: Russia unleashed its latest missile and drone strike on Kyiv, killing at least seven people, as Moscow steps up its aerial attacks on civilian infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Aliaksandr Kudrytski, Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: Firefighters tackle a blaze at an apartment building after a Russian attack, in Kyiv, on June 23. Photographer: Efrem Lukatsky/AP Photo

item.title: Philippines VP Sara Duterte Asks Senate to Dismiss Impeachment Case
item.description: Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte has asked the Senate to dismiss the impeachment case against her as it violated the one-year ban set under the constitution.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte Photographer: JAM STA ROSA/AFP

item.title: What If Iran Tries to Close the Strait of Hormuz?
item.description: Iran’s government has said it’s reserving all options to defend itself after the US joined Israel’s bombardment of the country’s nuclear sites. One way it could pressure its enemies to relent would be to block or effectively close the Strait of Hormuz to shipping.
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee
